title: How to Clear a Eustachian Tube Blockage

steps.title: Recognize the symptoms of a blockage.
steps.content: Recognize the symptoms of a blockage. Check your symptoms if you think you might have a Eustachian tube blockage in your ears. Some common symptoms of this type of ear problem include: [1] X Research source Ear popping Ringing in the ears Feeling of ear fullness Mild hearing loss Occasional poor balance

steps.title: Try yawning.
steps.content: Try yawning. This simple exercise is often quite effective at removing Eustachian tube blockage because the muscles used in the movement are quite strong. Yawning can help to equalize the pressure in the middle ear by temporarily opening your Eustachian tubes, which allows the air to flow out of the middle ear. [2] X Research source You may need to attempt several yawns before you feel the popping motion that indicates a pressure release.

steps.title: Chew gum.
steps.content: Chew gum. Try popping a piece of gum in your mouth and chewing it for a while if you’re having trouble with your Eustachian tubes hurting or feeling clogged. The chewing motion, combined with the swallowing motion, is a great way to naturally get your ears to pop. [3] X Research source You can also try eating, drinking, or any other activity that promotes a swallowing reflex.

steps.title: Blow air through your nose while you hold it shut.
steps.content: Blow air through your nose while you hold it shut. Try keeping your mouth shut while you plug your nose with your fingers. Gently blow out through your nose like you would if you were blowing your nose. This will redirect the air to help your ears pop as you hold your nose shut. You should hear a small popping sound in your ears that means the blockage of your Eustachian tubes is lessening.
Be sure not to blow too hard, as this could cause your eardrum to perforate.

steps.title: Apply a hot compress.
steps.content: Apply a hot compress. Take a warm face cloth or heating pad (on the low setting) and place it on your face so that it is overlapping your sinus cavities and draping down the side of your face over the clogged ear. You should cover your cheek and eye socket on the side of your face with the blockage. [4] X Research source Make sure the cloth is not too hot, as this could potentially burn your skin. You might want to consider placing a dry cloth between your skin and the heating pad to protect the skin from burning.

steps.title: Use nasal decongestant spray.
steps.content: Use nasal decongestant spray. One of the quickest ways to help your Eustachian tube blockage is to use a spray that is meant to help decongest your nasal cavity. Just remember that this relief will only be temporary, so you will need to continue treating the symptoms until the blockage is gone. [5] X Research source Try an over-the-counter nasal decongestant spray like Afrin, or a stronger prescription type recommended by your doctor. This is a great option if you are trying to clear your Eustachian tubes in a hurry, such as before a flight.

steps.title: Take an oral decongestant medication.
steps.content: Take an oral decongestant medication. These types of medications can be quite effective in treating blocked Eustachian tubes. You can find them at your local pharmacy, but they are often regulated. So you will probably have to ask for them specifically and provide the pharmacy with a copy of your identification card when you purchase them. [6] X Research source Look for ingredients like pseudoephedrine or phenylephrine. These kinds of oral decongestants can cause side effects like heart palpitations or a rise in blood pressure.

steps.title: Use a nasal wash.
steps.content: Use a nasal wash . Nasal washes are intended to help clean out the nasal cavity and remove any possible irritants. As these irritants can often cause problems with the Eustachian tubes, this can be an effective source of treatment for Eustachian tube blockage. To use a nasal wash, tilt your head sideways over a sink and pour the nasal wash solution into the nostril that is closest to the ceiling. The solution will rinse out your nasal cavities and drain out the other nostril into the sink. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source These types of treatments come in the forms of saline rinses, sprays, and neti pots.

steps.title: Visit your doctor.
steps.content: Visit your doctor. If you are having trouble clearing a Eustachian tube blockage on your own, consider making an appointment with your doctor. You’ll need to describe your symptoms so your doctor can advise you on the best course of action. Be sure to schedule an appointment with your doctor right away if you have a headache that continues for more than a couple days, or if there is pain associated with your Eustachian tube blockage.

steps.title: Consider getting PET tubes.
steps.content: Consider getting PET tubes. If you have chronic Eustachian tube blockage, you may want to talk to your doctor about the possibility of corrective tubal surgery. In severe cases, your doctor may recommend placing a pressure equalization tube (PET) in your eardrum in a fairly minor surgical procedure. [8] X Trustworthy Source FamilyDoctor.org Family-focused medical advice site run by the American Academy of Family Doctors Go to source This surgery is quite common in young children who have recurrent ear infections because of poor-functioning Eustachian tubes.

steps.title: Get myringotomy.
steps.content: Get myringotomy. In this minor surgery, your doctor will make a tiny incision in your eardrum that allow access to any fluid that has built up so it can be suctioned out. The incision may need to remain open for a little while to allow the swelling of the Eustachian tube lining to go down. Discuss this option with your doctor and decide if it is the right path for your treatment.
